Within the next hour, after another plane had slammed into the second tower of the World Trade Center, we understood that our world had changed forever.
Our home was located not far from the newspaper.
The Boston Globe is located across Dorchester Bay from Logan Airport.
As I drove my husband to work, we listened to the radio news broadcasters.

Like us, they were in flux, struggling to make sense of those burning towers in lower Manhattan, to gather the facts of how two jetliners had slammed into those buildings within an hour of each other.
The local newscaster said that the FAA had suspended all air travel and ordered all planes currently flying to land immediately.
In the backseat of our car, my daughter sucked her fingers and listened, her eyes wide.
We tried not to convey our fear and anxiety to her, but it was inevitable.
Then, as we turned onto Morrissey Boulevard in Boston, a long, busy street that runs parallel to Dorchester Bay and Logan Airport, we saw vivid evidence of what had happened in lower Manhattan.
In the clear blue sky above us, one massive jetliner after another was returning to Logan.
To say returning is understating it.
The jets, seemingly a minute or so apart, were descending so rapidly and at such low altitudes that we could hear their engines roaring.
They made a frightening sound, a low, whining scream, and their silver bullet-shaped bodies glinting in the bright sunlight seemed in danger of scraping tops of surrounding buildings.
The rest of the day is a blur.
I remember calling my daughter's daycare provider and asking if she might watch the toddler for a few hours.
I had a column to write for the Web site Africana.com, and while I hadn't planned to write about the attacks, I felt so unsettled that it seemed like the right choice.
In the end, I did write a column that day.
But I also watched the nonstop coverage of the attacks.
In between, I fielded phone calls from friends and family members across the country.
I'm just calling to make sure you didn't have a trip west planned.
You know that two of those planes came from Boston, said several of my friends and family members in northern California.
I told them, no, I'm here; and yes, I know that two of the planes originated at Logan.
One of the two jets had been bound for San Francisco, my hometown.
And in the past I had indeed taken that early flight from Logan to San Francisco International.
I tried not to think of what those passengers must have experienced as they realized what was happening to them on that morning.
All I know is that in the five years since that clear, dry, blue sky morning, I haven't forgotten that terrible noise above Boston.
The screaming, roaring sound of those jets flying low and fast, seeking safe ground again at Logan Airport.
